Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Situation2: They notice a local festival happening nearby and casually stop to observe some of the decorations and rituals.
Story:
I was walking home from school when I noticed the bright marigold garlands and the sound of temple bells drifting through the air. The local temple was alive with celebration—today was a festival day, and I felt a pull to join in, to be part of the rituals and the joy that comes with being Hindu. I lingered at the edge of the crowd, watching women in colorful saris light lamps and children my age laughing as they circled the temple. My heart ached to be among them, to feel the warmth of the community and the comfort of tradition.

But then I remembered my parents waiting at home. Lately, they seemed quieter, more tired, and I’d promised myself to check in on them, to ask if everything was okay. They counted on me to notice, to care, to be the child who offered support when things felt heavy. I stood there, torn between the call of my faith and the needs of my family, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me, unsure which path to take.
